awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Autonomous 3D Printer/Former for On-Site, Affordable Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to make possible small-scale, high-quality automated construction. This proposal investigates a method to automate the concrete forming process from design to construction, including site assessment, design, and material construction.  This platform can provide fast on-site construction, reduce renovation timelines, and provide habitat affordability.

This project advances translation of an automated concrete forming process, including concrete material formulations, robotic path planning/ machine vision for construction sites, and end-effector electromechanical designs. Other processes to be engineered include 3D mapping of existing site conditions, associated design processes, robotic path planning and material scheduling, and project execution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through this NSF SBIR Phase I project, Inzio developed the physical and digital technology required to create a mobile, autonomous 3D material forming system (patent processing) derived from modified commercially available excavators (BobCat E32 and E35 models) that have been converted into autonomous robotic systems, through the development of conversion kits. The conversion kit emulates the capabilities of a human (tactile force, motion control, vision, intelligence, etc.) combined with a forming system as the end effector on the excavator, along with wireless sensors and communications. Fusing these elements in the field allows for automated and digital construction practice for forming, pouring, motion coordination, safety, and building structures.

The robotic units are being combined with digital design elements, path planning, regional specific designs, and material instructions to create a novel cyber-physical 3D forming workflow for structure building in the field. These advancements enable potential users and customers to create digital content, designs, and establish end-to-end process workflows with automated or remote-control features. Furthermore, an on-site augmented reality application was also created as part of the project, providing users with the ability to digitally visualize the appearance of structures, optimize workspace utilization and AEC placement, and access digital information automated forming practices.

The initial intended application space for the technology was low-cost housing in impoverished and developing areas, looking to increase accessibility to higher quality construction equipment by lowering down hours and the number of humans involved, all reducing cost and making the build process more efficient and safer. This remains a long-term goal, but based on customer discovery, cost of entry and building code regulation challenges and complexities for a budding technology, the team decided to shift the short-term application space to coastal structures and submersible habitat infrastructure. Before the end of the project, Inzio has already made several test structures with characteristics of natural coral reefs using the automated forming excavator, enabled by the developed conversion kit.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2023
Modified by: Thea Fries
